text: The Agents drive past Abel, who is seated on a park bench overlooking the East River, painting.
(to Driver) Go ahead and park around the corner.

Abel sets down his palette. Close on his hand, adjusting his easel, then feeling unde the bench. His hand closes on something held by a magnet the bench’s steel frame below the wood seat-slats: it is nickel. Back to Abel sitting. Picks up his palette...
A seedy part of town. Abel walks toward a building, the HOTEL LATHAM.

As Abel lets himself in. A very modest room. He sets down his portable easel and case. Sets his work-in-progress canvass on a standing easel, drapes his jacket over a cha hangs his hat on the easel. He turns on a table fan. He fishes the nickel from his pocket, retrieves a razor f the bathroom and uses it to carefully to open it. It is hollow. Inside is a piece of paper, folded accordion-style into a small square. Abel unfolds it. Holds it up to a magnifier lamp. Written on the paper, a sequence of numerals.
Two government cars skid to a stop and the Agents pour ou

The Agents run down the corridor.  12.17.14 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 3. ABEL’S ROOM Its door is being busted in. The Agents swarm in. They have guns. They come up short. The small room is empty. The easel with a work in progres upon it stands before the window, which stands open, gent wind playing at the sheers. Outside, a fire escape. The man seems to have left. An Agent inspects a closed door. The bathroom -- Rudolf Abel steps out, in his briefs. Standing in the doorway, cigarette in mouth, we see him as a frail, vulnerable old man. He freezes, not scared, just surprised. He looks at the m They look at him. At last he speaks, with colorless, quasi-British accent.
Visitors. A beat.
..-Would you mind if I fetch my teeth? Two of the agents, Blasco and Gamber, look at each other, confused. Abel gestures back towards the bathroom.
Colonel, would you turn around please. Blasco turns Abel around, checks to make sure he’s not ar
Sit down. On the bed. Blasco and Gamber walk him to the bed. He sits.
(gesturing toward bathroom) The teeth are on the sink... (CONTINUED)
Look at me! We are agents from the federal government. Abel scans the Agents who surround him.

Look at me! I’m talking to you. We have received information concerning your involvement in espionage. You can either cooperate with us right now or you’ll be under arrest. Do you understand, Colonel? Blasco heads into the bathroom.
Not really. Why do you keep calling me “Colonel”? Blasco returns and with care hands him his teeth. Abel pu them in.
You need to get dressed.
We have to search your apartment. Abel points at the art materials on the table.
Would you mind if I cleaned my palette? The paints will get ruined otherwise. Just behind you there. I have a cloth, myself... Abel stands. Blasco hands him his palette.
Thank you.
(to the other men) Start searching, please.
Would you put this out in the ashtray. On the windowsill there. (CONTINUED)

While an Agent does this and the other Agents begin the search, Abel, holding the palette, grabs a small scrap of paper -- the one from the nickel bearing a series of numerals. As the agents explore the room, Abel uses the paper to wi the palette clean.
Don’t want this to get spoiled. The wet paint obliterates the code. As the agents continu to toss the room...
Mellow jazz piano...
Two middle-aged men sit in club chairs facing each other. Each holds a tumbler of scotch.
Don't say “my guy.” He’s not “my guy.”
Yes he’s your guy. Who’re we talking about?
We're talking about a guy who is insured by my client. So don’t make him “my guy.”
Okay, fine, my point is he -- the guy insured by your client -- he doesn’t deny any of these things happened --
“These things?”
Yes. These five things.
Wait. Hold it, hold it, hold it. Not five things, one thing. (CONTINUED)
Clearly, it’s five things.
Well -- I’m sorry -- it’s not clear to me. Five things? Explain it to me.
It’s self-evident.
Okay, then tell me what happened, tell me the story in a way that makes sense. For five things.
Fine. Absolutely. Your guy --
Not my guy. Insured by my client.

The guy insured by your client -- is driving down State Highway 19 when he loses control of his car, hits my five guys. The five guys who hired me to represent them because you’re not honoring your claim.
You mean my client is not honoring the claim. The insurance company.
Mr. Donovan: we’re all clear on who’s who here.

Except, my client honors every claim. They do, Mr. Bates, every single legitimate claim. Up to the limit of their liability, which is $100,000 per accident in the case of this man’s policy. And this is one claim, according to your description. “He hit my five guys.” The guy insured by my client had one accident, one one one, losing control of the car and hitting five motorcyclists. (CONTINUED)
From their point of view, five things happened.
Look Bob -- may I? Bob? (gestures to self) Jim. If I go bowling and I throw a strike, one thing happened. Ten things didn’t happen.
Jim. My clients are not bowling pins. As much your guy might have treated them so --

Lemme finish. If your house is insured to $100,000 and a tornado carries it away, it carried away one house. It didn’t pick up every stick of furniture and destroy it in a separate incident. If that’s what you're saying, well, then there is never any limit to our liability and that is the end of the insurance business. And then, Bob, nobody is safe.
Donovan steps into a plush office suite. The receptionist works a busy switchboard.
Watters, Cowan and Donovan, how may I direct your call? Alison, Donovan's secretary, steps over with his mail.
Good morning, Alison.
Morning, Mr. Donovan. I moved your nine a.m. with Prudential, sir.
Why did you do that?
I asked her to -- (CONTINUED)
Donovan turns to find his senior partner, THOMAS WATTERS (70s), watching him closely.
Everything alright, Tom?

Why don’t you leave your stuff with Alison, c’mon inside. Donovan sets his briefcase, mail and hat down and follows Watters. WATTERS (CONT’D) Something pretty important has come up and there’s someone here to see us. Natalie’1ll get your coffee. (To Watters' secretary Natalie) Nescafé, no cream, two lumps. Right?
That's right, thanks. He looks concerned. WATTER’S OFFICE Lynn Goodnough (50s), Chairman of the New York Bar, smile Watters and Donovan enter. Goodnough shakes Donovan’s han
Jim, nice to see you again. How's the family?
Great, good, thanks. How’s Annie? Natalie enters with Donovan’s coffee, sets in on desk.
Homicidal, we had the in-laws for the holiday. Watters sits on his desk.
Well, if she acts on it she’1l have good representation. Chuckles. (CONTINUED)
What’s up? Natalie leaves. All three men take their seats.

Okay. Here’s the thing. The Soviet spy they caught. We want you to defend him. (pause) Here’s the indictment. Slap! -- he drops a thick document onto the coffee table. Silence. Donovan looks at it but doesn’t reach for it. He is absorbing the news.
Well. More silence.
...I’m not sure I should pick that up.
The accused doesn’t know any lawyers. The Federal Court tossed it into our lap. The Bar Committee took a vote. You were the unanimous choice.
It was important to us -- it’s important to our country, Jim -- that this man is seen as getting a fair shake. American justice will be on trial.
Well, of course, when you put it that way, it’s an honor to be asked. But -- Lynn -- I’m an insurance lawyer, I haven't done criminal work in years.
Well it’s like riding a bike, isn’t it? You distinguished yourself at Nuremberg. (CONTINUED)
I was on the prosecution team.
Not the point: you’re no stranger to criminal law. Jim, look at the situation. The man is publicly reviled.
And I will be too.
Yes, in more ignorant quarters. But that’s exactly why this has to be done -- and capably done. It can’t look like our justice system tosses people on the ash heap. Thinking beat.
Suppose I did...what’s the evidence look like?
Pretty overwhelming.
Great. Great. Everyone will hate me, but at least I’ll lose. (to Watters) What do you think, Tom? The firm’1l suffer, I have work here.

I think it’s a patriotic duty, this is an important mission. I told Lynn the firm can’t say no, and you'd have a tough time saying no too. I think you have to defend the sonofabitch. DONOVAN’S OFFICE On young attorney Doug Forrester.
So you're doing it?
Doing what? (CONTINUED)
Defending Abel, the Soviet spy. Widen to include Donovan, seated at his desk, Forrester standing in front of him.
I may be. Hey how do you know? Did they post it on the bulletin board?
I was just talking to Richard --
If I do this? I’m going to need your help. Doug sits, beams, until -
Can you work tonight?
Well, I have a dinner date, sir... Donovan gives him a hard look.
(back-peddling) It’s Tuesday, right? No I can cancel. No problem. As Doug stands and exits, Donovan chuckles to himself.
The family is at the dinner table. Mary exits from the kitchen with plates of food.
...-But it’s also an honor. And the bar association asked me because they want to demonstrate that even this spy gets a capable advocate. We hear the door opening, off.
Well maybe it’s the kind of honor we can do without. People are scared, they’re -- Carol walks in. (CONTINUED)
Hi honey, what are you doing home?
I got stood up.
What? That’s despicable. Who’s this knot head?
I’d rather not say.
Well sit down, we just started. (to Donovan) ...People are scared, they’re building bomb shelters to protect themselves from people like this man.
Roger. Make another place setting for your sister. Roger does as instructed.
(to Donovan) I go to the store, people are buying canned foods and potassium tablets. It’s all about this man and what he represents, he’s a threat to all of us, a traitor --
Who's a traitor?
The Rosenbergs were traitors --
Who are they?
They gave atomic secrets to the Russians. They were Americans, they betrayed their country. But you can’t accuse Abel of being a traitor, he’s not an American. 12. (CONTINUED)
Listen to yourself. You're defending him already. You're rehearsing it on me. You said you were just thinking about taking it.
Well I am just thinking about it -- just very hard. Everyone deserves a defense. Every person matters.
Jim, what do we deserve? You know how people will look at us? The family of a man trying to free a traitor?
He’s not a traitor, Mary-- The doorbell.
Roger get that.
Why do I have to do all the work around here? Peggy reaches for a dinner roll.
Wait till we say grace!
I’m hungry!
(to Donovan) He’s about the most unpopular man in the country -- and you're trying to take second place.
Yeah, and I’m third.
No, Carol, you just made a date with the wrong guy. (to Mary) Mary, don’t make us disagree if we're not disagreeing, you're against the guy, I’m for him? (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

Huh-uh. I’m not for the guy, I’m not for Russians spying on us. I’m for his right to have a defense in a court of law. That’s why we call it a court of law... Roger walks back in leading Doug Forrester who is carryin stack of books. Carol stiffens.
Hello, sir, sorry -- didn’t mean to interrupt your dinner.
(still focused on Mary) A court of law and not a...not a... Hey, Doug. And not a kangaroo court.
(to Doug) Oh not at all, hello Doug -- Jim was just flailing.
I'm not flailing...go ahead, Doug, you can join us for dinner, we’re having meat loaf tonight.
(ignoring Donovan, eying Doug's books) So you came over to help Jim think about whether he’s taking the case. Doug, deaf to the irony, is innocently enthusiastic:

Oh, we're taking it! It’s exciting, isn’t it? Mary stares daggers at Donovan. Doug realizes he’s steppe in it. Donovan, abashed, starts saying grace, extends his hand to Mary, who doesn’t hold it so much as slap it...
Abel is led by a guard into a detention room where Donova awaits.  12.17.14 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 15.

Good morning, sir. My name is Jim Donovan. These are my credentials -- Both men stand looking at each other, Abel still at the threshold. After a beat he moves in further, his gaze holding on Don who glances at papers on table

I’m a partner at Watters, Cowan and Donovan. I was admitted to the New York Bar in 1941. As the guard slams the door shut, Abel picks up the paper and inspects them. Donovan watches him, trying to read hi

«..-You’ve been charged with three counts and nineteen overt acts; conspiracy to transmit United States defense and atomic secrets to the Soviet Union; conspiracy to gather secrets; and failing to register as a foreign agent.
Do many foreign agents register? Only now does Abel look up from the credentials up to Donovan. Donovan takes a moment, not sure if he’s being kidded. He takes a seat at the table.
If you don’t mind my asking, sir, since your arrest: where have you been?
I couldn't say for certain.
You don’t know. Abel takes a seat.
They drove me to an airport, put me on a plane. They took me off the plane. Somewhere hot. (CONTINUED)
It’s hot here.
Hotter. Very humid. They put me in a room. Abel attends to his runny nose with a handkerchief.
Were you beaten?
No. I was...talked to. Offers were made.
What do you mean?
Offers of employment. To work for your government. I was told if I cooperated no further charges would be made against me, and I would be given money.
And you declined.
As you see.
Well of course, I can’t endorse that. I feel duty bound to urge you to cooperate with the U.S. Government.
Well, I said no. Perhaps you could relay to your friends at the CIA that I meant it.
No no, I don’t work for the agency. I don’t work for the government. I’m here to offer my services as your legal counsel. If you accept them as such, I work for you.
If I accept you? Are you good at what you do? (CONTINUED)
Yeah, I’m pretty good.
Have you represented many accused spies?
No. Not yet. This will be a first for the both of us. Abel chuckles, looks again at Donovan's credentials.
All right.
All right you accept?
Yes, all right.
Good, okay, let’s start here. If you are firm in your resolve not to cooperate with the U.S. government --
I am.

Yeah, then do not talk to anyone else about your case. Inside of government or out. Except to me -- to the extent that you trust me. I have a mandate to serve you. Nobody else does. Quite frankly, everybody else has an interest in sending you to the electric chair.
All right.
You don’t seem alarmed. Abel shrugs.
Would it help? Abel watches Donovan for another moment. Amused. Pulls ou a pad of paper and starts writing. (CONTINUED)
I'd like materials. To draw with.
That's not possible.
A pencil. A piece of paper. And cigarettes. Please. The show of manners surprises Donovan. Abel watches him.
Mr. Donovan, you have men like me doing the same for your country. If they were caught, I’m sure you'd wish them to be treated well.
A cheap room with the curtains drawn. An athletic-looking man in uniform is seated on a chair.
What’s your name?
Francis Gary Powers. Wider: he is strapped to a lie detector.
Rank, service.
First Lieutenant. United States Air Force.
Do you have any association with the Soviet Union, Lieutenant Powers?
Are you kiddin?
Just answer the questions, Lieutenant, yes/no or as simply as you can. Do you have any association with the Soviet Union? (CONTINUED)
Hell no.
Do you know why you’re here?
Uh-uh.
Is that a no?
Yes. I mean no. It’s just no. (turning to the interrogator) Yes, I have absolutely no idea why I’m here.
Eyes front, Lieutenant. Powers turns back.
Yes sir.

We are wide looking at the fluorescent-lit arcade of room a motel with a cheap neon sign. Night crickets. The door one room opens and Powers and an escort emerge: Powers is down the row of doors to another, and he is shown in.
Three other pilots are inside, smoking, playing cards, waiting.
How'd ya do in there, Gary?
Pretty good. Think I got my name right.
Probably outscored Shinn, then. Powers sits.
Who's winnin’? (CONTINUED)
That would be me.
Deal me in. An officer enters the room and the banter stops. The pilo stand. The officer chuckles and gestures for them to sit. He turns off the flickering TV, takes a seat.

Okay, drivers, here’s the deal. You have been selected for a mission which you are not to discuss with anyone outside of this room. No one. I don’t care who you trust -- wife, mother, sweetheart, the good lord when you pray at night -- you don’t tell any of ‘em anything of what I’m about to tell you. Each of you drivers has met certain qualifications -- high level security clearance, exceptional pilot ratings, in excess of the required hours flight time ina single seat aircraft. We are engaged in a war. This war does not -- for the moment -- involve men at arms. It involves information. You will be collecting information. You will be gathering intelligence about the enemy -- the intelligence you gather could give us the upper hand in a full thermonuclear exchange with the Soviet Union. Or it could prevent one. For public purposes -- as far as your wife or mother or sweetheart or the good lord above -- your mission does not exist. If it does not exist you do not exist. You cannot be shot down. You cannot be captured. He stands.
You work for the CIA now. He smiles, turns, and exits. On the now wary pilots.  12.17.14 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 21. BROOKLYN COURTHOUSE -- JUDGE BYERS’ CHAMBERS Judge Byers fixes his tie in a mirror.
So, Jim, I heard your guy is speaking with a phony accent. Does he keep that up all the time? He turns to Donovan and Assistant Attorney General Willia Tompkins.
Actually I’m pretty sure that’s just the way he talks. He’s got the Russian name but a British passport.
Well I doubt that’s genuine.
So, Jim, where are we at? I see here you, uh... He is leaning forward, peering through his glasses at a p on his desk. He takes a seat, as do Donovan and Tompkins.
Yes, Judge, I -- I just don’t think three weeks is gonna do it here; we've got a massive amount of evidence here --
You wanna postpone --
Six weeks, I mean there’s just myself and my associate, basically --
Jim. Is this serious?
Sir?
Is this serious?
Yes. Indeed it is. It’s, you’ll see in the filing -- (CONTINUED)
Jim, this man is a Soviet spy.
..-Allegedly, yeah --
C’mon counselor.
Your honor!

Of course I salute you, we all salute you for taking on a thankless task. This man has to have due process, but let’s not kid each other. A knock at the door. He stands stand. JUDGE BYERS (CONT’D) He'll receive a capable defense and, god willing, he'll be convicted. C’mon, counselor, let’s not play games with this. 22. and heads for the door. Donovan and Tompkins JUDGE BYERS (CONT’D) Not in my courtroom. We have a date and we're going to trial. He opens the door and walks through it.
It is evening. It’s pouring rain. Donovan exits the building with his briefcase and umbrell A taxi approaches. But it pas Donovan ye
Taxi! ses straight by. lls after it:
I see your light on! Sonofabitch. (CONTINUED)
He sees another man across the street and says, re: the cabbie:
Can’t wait to get back to Manhattan... His light was on, right? The man just stands, smoking. Donovan looks around, still angry. No cabs. He starts walking.

.--Sonofabitch. He walks on. He hears another set of footsteps. He looks around. A man behind. Donovan experiments with picking up his pace. The man behind seems to match it. The pursuer is briefly blocked by several men exiting an apartment building. Donovan uses this moment to crouch behind a car, trying t control his breathing. Quiet. The pursuer runs as far as the corner. The footsteps stop. A beat as the pursuer surveys the emp street. Then they resume, coming closer, and the man circles the parked car to look down at Donovan.
Mr. Donovan. Donovan is unsure whether to be embarrassed or afraid.
What? He rises and stares the man down. Donovan’s angry.
What?  12.17.14 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 24.
Donovan faces the man, looking at identification, which h hands back.
Yeah. Just wanted to chat. How’s the case going?
The case is going great. Couldn't be better.
Uh-huh. Has your guy talked?
...Excuse me?
You met him, has he talked? Has he said anything yet? Donovan stares at him. Then:
We’re not having this conversation. (CONTINUED)
The man nods agreeably.
No, of course not.
No, I mean we're really not having it. You're asking me to violate attorney-client privilege.
Oh c’mon counselor, you --
And I wish people like you would quit saying “Oh c’mon, counselor.” I didn’t like it the first time it happened today, a judge said it to me twice, and the more I hear it, the more I don’t like it.

Ok, well listen, I understand attorney-client privilege. I understand all the legal gamesmanship and I understand that that’s how you make a living. But I’m talking to you about something else -- the security of your country. I’m sorry if the way I put it offends you, but we need to know what Abel is telling you. You understand me, Donovan? We need to know. Don’t go Boy Scout on me -- we don’t have a rule book here. Donovan takes a beat, sizing the man up.
You're agent Hoffman, yeah?
Yeah.
German extraction?
Yeah, so?
My name is Donovan, Irish. Both sides, mother and father. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

I'm Irish, you're German, but what makes us both Americans? Just one thing, one one one. The rule book. We call it the Constitution. We agree to the rules, and that’s what makes us Americans, it’s all that makes us Americans. So don’t tell me there’s no rule book and don’t nod at me like that you sonofabitch. The man stops nodding and just looks at Donovan appraisin him. Donovan smiles and gets up from the table, gathers h things.
Do we need to worry about you?
Not if I’m left alone to do my job. He grabs a peanut from the dish on the table and walks aw as he pops it into his mouth.
The doors of the hangar split like a metal curtain and ro back. Powers and the other pilots stare in, expectantly.
Sitting in the shadows is a huge black aircraft. The streamlined body of a glider, enormous wings. The U-2. Th pilots begin to surround it, examining it.

From this moment forward, you will not refer to the U-2 as a spy plane or reconnaissance aircraft. You will refer to it as “the article.” “The article” has an eighty-foot wingspan. Powered by a single Pratt and Whitney J57 P37 engine. 10,000 pounds of thrust. Maximum speed of 430 miles an hour. She may not be quick but at your cruising altitude of 70,000 feet, nothing will come close to you.
Seventy-thousand. (CONTINUED)
The idea is the enemy doesn’t even know you’re there. Powers smiles; it’s the most beautiful thing he’s ever se The other pilots fan out. Joe Murphy looks at the tail attached with three short bolts.
Looks kinda flimsy.
Every extra pound of weight costs a foot in altitude and we need to accommodate the cameras. The pilots gather around a structure on which is mounted several camera lenses.

That’s a thirty-inch lens. A pin- sharp panoramic camera. Four times as powerful as any aerial reconnaissance cameras we've ever used. You’re gonna be taking pictures. Lots of pictures. At 70,000 feet “the article” can photograph 2,000 square miles of territory in one pass. Now, drivers, give Agent Sumner your undivided attention. Sumner directs them to a table festooned with gear of all kinds.
The items you will need on your mission are here.
Donovan and Doug Forrester stand in front of twenty-five large trestle tables covered with the equipment seized fr Abel’s studio. Agent Blasco is reading through a list.
A hollow-handled shaving brush; a complete set of cipher tablets on edible silver foil; specialist photographic equipment --
Yeah, we get the idea. Thank you. (CONTINUED)
Blasco grudgingly hands over the list and steps away. Donovan examines the list. He notices something on the paper.
Excuse me, agent Bosco. Blasco?.
Sir?
There seems to be a sub-section to this list here.
Well most of this stuff came from his studio. But the rest was from the hotel room he was holed up in. Where we found him.
The hotel room you searched?
Well, yeah.
Can I see the warrant?

What? BROOKLYN COURTHOUSE -- JUDGE BYER’S CHAMBERS Donovan watches as Judge Byers looks through his half-gla at a document on the desk before him. Forrester is standi further back by the door as is Asst. Attorney General Tompkins.
Yeah, explain this to me? There was a warrant.
Well, there was a warrant, a civil detention writ -- for the arrest of an alien. But there was no search warrant for suspicion of criminal activity. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)
He stands.
As people 12.17.14 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 29.
So that search, and the evidence that is the fruit of that search, that’s all tainted and should not be admitted.
What protections is he due, your honor? The man is not -- the man is, what, “Rudolf Ivanovich Abel,” he is a Soviet citizen, he is not an American.

1886, Yick Wo v. Hopkins, the court held that even aliens, in that case, Chinese immigrants, could not be held to answer for a crime without due process of law...including any alien that entered this country illegally --

The Department of Justice has its first allegiance to the United States. I don’t see how an alien, if he’s here illegally, how he suffered deprivation of rights. Rights as what? An American? Rights as what, counselor? In no uncertain terms: JUDGE BYERS (CONT’D) We are in a battle for civilization. This Russian spy came here to threaten our way of life. Now we have a courtroom of people waiting. Get out there, sit beside the Russian, and let’s get this over and done with. And your motion is denied. take their seats, Tompkins turns to the man next to him and glancing at Donovan, says:
He should take some insurance out on himself. (CONTINUED)
Abel is sitting next to Donovan.
How did we do?
In there? (gropes) Not too good. Apparently you’re not an American citizen.
That’s true. He dabs at his nose with his handkerchief.
And according to your boss, you're not a Soviet citizen either. Abel is always mild:
Well...The boss isn’t always right but he’s always the boss. Donovan looks at him.
Do you never worry?
(shrug) Would it help? A door opens by the judge’s bench and Judge Byers enters. There is general movement as the bailiff calls:
All rise.
Every child rises to his feet. With hands on hearts, they begin to recite the Pledge of Allegiance.

text: First, you have to know what happens when an atomic bomb explodes. (CONTINUED)

Kids watching in a classroom. Roger Donovan is among them NARRATOR (CONT’D) .-.-There is a bright flash, brighter than the sun. Onscreen we see footage of trees rocking wildly from the blast. An animation of an idyllic house. with a tree and hayrick a field. Suddenly an atomic explosion rips the house sideways. Glass flies, branches are blown through the air straw and leaves are sucked violently past. Faces of students -- riveted, hardly breathing -- a girl scared to tears. NARRATOR (CONT’D) ...-It can smash in buildings, and break windows all over town. But if you duck and cover, like Burt -- Animation of Burt the Turtle. NARRATOR (CONT’D) You’1l be much safer. ON ROGER, apprehensive. NARRATOR (CONT’D) There are two kinds of attack. With warning, and without any warning...
Donovan opens the bathroom door. He looks in on his son, has filled the bathtub to the very top with water. Roger a bruise under one eye.
Hm. what’s going on in here?

Okay Dad, this is really important. When the war begins, the first thing they do is cut off all the water and all the electricity. So the first thing we should do is keep this filled, and use the shower in your room, use the sink downstairs, the garden house outside -- (CONTINUED)
Those are good ideas. But Roger, I don’t see this as being something you ever have to worry about.
But when you hear the sirens, there may not be enough time to fill up the tub and the sinks.
There are not going to be any sirens. What is this? Roger lifts a drawing he made, from a small table strewn magazine articles.

When the bomb comes, the Reds will aim for the Empire State Building. But the bomb goes off at 10,000 feet up. In Life Magazine, it’s called an airburst and if the bomb is 50 megatons, the “blast wave” goes out, and out, and out, and melts everything from here to here (points to his drawing)-- including where we live...here. Donovan takes the drawing, sits down on the covered toile
Roger, nobody’s dropping atomic bombs on us.
But the Russians want to. You know the guy you’re defending, he’s here to get things ready for the guys who drop the bombs...
He isn’t here for that. And he’s not even a Russian...he was born, we think, in Northern England.
But he’s a spy for Russia. I don’t even understand what you're doing. You're not a Communist, so why are you defending one? (CONTINUED)
Because it’s my job.
It never used to be.
Donovan, seated on a crowded train, looks around at other passengers reading the various newspapers. A page four banner headline reads: “AFTER TEN DAYS OF TESTIMONY -- ABEL SPY CASE GOES TO THE

There is also a picture of Donovan standing next to Abel. few passengers on the subway lift their eyes from their papers, recognizing Donovan. Donovan feels like everyone' looking at him and not kindly.
The foreman of the jury stands, sensing every eye on him. The public gallery is full.
In the case of the United States of America versus Rudolf Abel, as to the first count in the indictment, how do you find the defendant? Guilty or not guilty? Donovan stands next to Abel.
Guilty.
As to the second count?
Guilty.
As to the third count?

There are only a few routes left to the East. You take the S-Bahn, the station we showed you on the way in. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

You're going to get off at the Friedrichstrasse Station, here, and walk to the Soviet Embassy on Unter den Linden, here. Look at the map now -- you shouldn’t take it with you. You're looking at a map, you're an American, you’re a spy, you could well be detained. Just avoid interaction with people, generally -- you don’t belong, so don’t stick out. Food is scarce over there and things have started to fall apart. There are gangs; rule of law is less...firmly established over there. And definitely stay away from the Wall. On their side, there’s a line cleared of buildings, along the Wall, they call it the Death Line. Cross it and you'll be shot.
Is there any outcome here where I’m not either detained, or shot?
Don’t worry too much about what Michener said.
No, now I’m worried about what you're saying. This kid Pryor, that the East German’s have. How old is he?
Twenty-five, why?
That’s the same age as Dougie.
Who?
An associate of mine...
Katje is sitting at a table in a bare room. Very still.
Frederic Pryor. (CONTINUED)
Katje is holding a picture of Frederic Pryor. The officia doesn’t even look at it, continues reading his newspaper. The following exchange is in German, subtitled.
I'm sorry, there is nothing I can tell you. After a deflated beat, a plea:
He’s not here, or you can’t tell me he’s here? Where is he? The man shrugs.
I can’t tell you.
Pryor sits at a small table in his cell, eating.

It is a gray day. Donovan sits looking out. His point-of- view: approaching the Wall. It comes at us, foreshortenin and then sweeps by: a ragged line stretching into the background, punctuated by guard towers. On its far side i swath of cleared land. Even beyond this Death Line many of the buildings of the are bombed out, the war damage still largely unrepaired. There is not much life in the streets.

Passengers disembarking, Donovan among the last. A long line stretching up to a checkpoint. Only one soldi checks papers, though many soldiers stand about. Donovan looks at his watch. Tense. He thinks, decides. He steps out of the line and marches to the front, drawin looks. Approaching the checkpoint: the soldier checking papers l up at him, surprised. This doesn’t happen. A couple soldiers tighten grips on their guns. (CONTINUED)

Donovan holds out his passport and summons a degree of sternness as, in broken German, he tries to explain his plight. The soldiers search his passport and wallet as he points at his watch urgently. The soldiers search his documents and slowly all of them begin to relax when they see he’s American. They let him pass.

Donovan walking. It is snowing heavily. He reaches an intersection. Several youths are gathered there -- mangy strays. They eye Donovan as they approach, slowing. He eyes them, not slowing. They pass, but several paces on Donovan senses something wrong. He turns. One of them, the biggest of the group, speaks to him in German. Clearly it is a question. They all look at him, awaiting answer. Donovan stares, uncomprehending. The big guy repeats the question. This time impatiently. He grabs Donovan’s coat by a lapel. Examines the material

So.... We apologize. If this offends? Donovan realizes they are demanding his coat. He asks for directions to Unter den Linden. The Head Youth points out the directions. Donovan shrugs out of the coat, ceding it.

Looking towards the street: Donovan is a small figure. He wears only his suit. He’s freezing. He runs. New angle: he stands before an imposing building, in good repair: the embassy. He heads for its door.  12.17.14 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 67.
Donovan comes to a reception desk.
Do you understand English?
Yes, sir.
I’m James Donovan. I’m here to meet a Mr. Vogel.
Mr. Vogel?
He doesn’t work here. I’m just supposed to meet him. That’s all I know.

Some minutes later. The receptionist is showing Donovan i though a series of magnificent rooms to a parlor of sorts There are three people in the room: a woman in her fiftie much younger woman, and an older man in a three-piece sui The older woman is effusively emotional and charges Donov weepily:
Mr. Donovan! So we finally meet you! She hugs him, Donovan stiffly unresponsive.
-..I am Helen Abel! How is our husband? How is Rudolf?
He’s... good as can be expected --
And we will get him back, yes? This is our daughter, Lydia...
How do you do? (to the older man) And you’re Mr. Vogel? (CONTINUED)
The man is momentarily thrown. He recovers, laughing:
No no no no. Not Vogel, no. I am cousin Drews. He vigorously shakes Donovan’s hand.
This is Rudolf’s beloved cousin Drews.
Yes. Cousin Drews.
I am Cousin Drews.
Cousin Drews, yes.
I’m Helen Abel! An awkward pause...
When will you see him? She pulls him down to a small sofa.
When will your government release him?
I’m sorry, I’m a little...lost here. I’m supposed to meet a Mr. Vogel.
Yes, Mr. Vogel is our lawyer.
Yes, and I thought we were supposed to negotiate the exchange.
To bring Rudolf here.
Well yes...yes, to bring him here, but it doesn’t happen unilaterally. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

Do you understand? It has to be an exchange... Helen bursts into tears. 69. Lydia puts an arm around her to comfort her. Cousin Drews kneels in front of the sobbing woman, comforting her as w Donovan dubiously watches this show. A door clicks open -- not the one Donovan entered by but set into a panel of the wall near the mirror behind the d A man enters.
Mr. Donovan. Donovan rises, extending a hand.
Mr. Vogel? Shaking hands, his manner dry, urbane:
No no, no. My name is Schischkin, Ivan Schischkin. I am second secretary of the Soviet Embassy. It would not be appropriate for Mr. Vogel to join us; he is a German national.
So you are...here to...

To facilitate this meeting. (to the group on the couch) Perhaps Mrs. Abel would like to compose herself privately? And let Mr. Donovan and myself to talk? The group takes the cue and leaves by the main door, face suddenly stern. Now the room is quiet. A beat.
So, I’m confused...
Yes. (CONTINUED)
I don’t care who I talk to if it’s about an exchange of...personnel. Are you the person to talk to?
Yes yes -- of course we should talk. Please, have a seat. Sit down. They sit opposite one another at a small table. SCHISCHKIN (CONT’D) So, how did you arrive in the Eastern sector?
The train. The S-Bahn.
You were alone?
Yup.
And you are credentialed --

You must know about me, sir. I'ma private citizen, a lawyer in Brooklyn -- in the United States -- and I’ve taken some time out of a busy schedule to help my client, Rudolf Abel. I’m authorized to arrange an exchange of Abel for Francis Gary Powers -- this is a full pardon of Abel (handing a paper across) that will be signed when the exchange actually takes place. That’s the only reason I’m here. I hope and expect to make this arrangement quickly -- Abel for Francis Gary Powers (a measured beat) and -- Frederic Pryor.
We don’t have Pryor.
No? You don’t? (CONTINUED)
I've heard of Pryor. But he is held by German Democratic Republic, not by the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. Schischkin hands him back the pardon.
Well, I’11 tell you the first problem, the names of your countries are too long. Schischkin smiles. Donovan's

If we release Powers it is only to promote good will between our countries. So it cannot be an exchange. Perhaps you could release Abel as a token of good will to our friends in Germany, and then some months later we would release Powers, there’s an idea.

No, that won’t work for us at all, you see we need this to be an exchange. You can call it what you want, but an exchange it must be. We can have Abel within forty-eight hours. We need Powers at the same time we give you Abel.
Well this is -- can we call this “The Impatient Plan”?
Call it whatever you want. cold’s getting worse. He blows his nose.
I can relay your Impatient Plan to Moscow, see what they say. But they will wonder, why so Impatient?
Because I have a cold, I don’t live in Berlin, and I want to get home. (CONTINUED)

They will think, well, the Americans must have gotten all the information that Abel had to give. And now they are now impatient to trade him, hoping to get in return this man Powers who perhaps has not yet given up the information that he has to give. This is not an equitable trade, sir.

But you’re saying, if Powers has given up everything he knows, then Moscow would trade? Why wouldn’t they? As for Abel, if he dies in an American prison, the next Russian operative who gets caught might think twice about keeping his mouth shut...(and now he tries something new) and, you never know, Abel might want to see the sky again and start to trade Russian secrets for very small American favors.
How can we know this. We little men, we just do our jobs.
Like Lt. Powers. He’s just a pilot.
He was making photographs from seventy thousand feet when he was shot from the sky. People in my country consider this an act of war.

We have to get off this merry go round, sir. The next mistake our countries make could be the last one. We need to have the conversation our governments can’t. Schischkin takes a moment to think. Donovan watches him a waits.
I will ask Moscow. Who knows what they will say? A lot of people, Mr. Donovan, don’t want this exchange to ever take place. (CONTINUED)
He rises. 12.17.14 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 73. (6)
As does Donovan. SCHISCHKIN (CONT’D) Can you come back tomorrow and discuss their answer? Powers for Abel.
And Frederic Pryor.
(patient) As I said, Pryor is in the hands of the organs of state security of the German Democratic Republic.
I’m confident you can make arrangements.
I am merely a secretary in the embassy of a foreign power.
Okay.
You’1ll have to see Mr. Vogel. I/’11 give you his address. Donovan looks at him for a beat.
...-There actually is a Mr. Vogel?
Why would you imagine otherwise? It’s a short cab ride. (writing) And please, Mr. Donovan, wear an overcoat in this weather.
I had mine stolen from me.
What did you expect? (handing him the address) It was from Saks Fifth Avenue. Wasn’t it? On Donovan, as this sinks in.  12.17.14 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 74.
A secretary shows Donovan in. A man better-dressed than h office would lead you to expect, is pouring two scotches: Wolfgang Vogel.
Mr. Donovan!
Mr. Vogel.
Please come in!
Sorry about the embassy, the Soviets decided not to host us, very irritating.
I am still trying to grasp each party’s...
Status?
Yes. And interest, in the proceedings.
Yes, a new world, all very disorienting isn’t it. He hands Donovan one of the tumblers, and they both drink

Let me tell you what I have to offer. I ama good friend -- friend, no, he is older -- protégé -- of the Attorney General of the German Democratic Republic. Sit down please. They sit across from each other at Vogel's desk.
This unfortunate Frederic Pryor, well, he was in the wrong place at the wrong time. But every accident, properly viewed, is an opportunity, isn’t it Mr. Donovan? (CONTINUED)
Well --
Your country refuses to recognize the German Democratic Republic. They prefer to make up stories -- that the GDR doesn’t exist, for instance. Donovan signals that his glass is empty.
Sorry. He rises to refill it.

As a means of forcing your government’s recognition of this real place, sir, in which you find yourself -- the GDR. The Attorney General is happy to negotiate with you, aS a representative of your government, for Mr. Pryor’s return.
Mr. Vogel, I’m not here as a representative of my government. Silent beat.
(sadly) All right. I think that’s childish, Mr. Donovan. Donovan shrugs.
Well, I have no official status.
...Fine, you do not represent the USA, I do not represent the GDR. My client is Lydia Abel, Rudolf’s wife, and I have also --
Lydia is the daughter. Helen is the wife. A beat, Vogel resentful at having his thought derailed. (CONTINUED)
Well. I -- am prepared to offer Frederic Pryor’s exchange, for Rudolph Abel’s. Donovan stands, faces off with him.
Well let’s be clear. We will produce Rudolf Abel. At the same time, you will produce, the student Pryor. At the same time.
Absolutely. Vogel takes a photograph from a file on his desk top. The photo is of an incarcerated Pryor, looking very young and very scared. He hands it to Donovan.
The exchange on offer is a Russian at the end of his life, for an American student at the start of his. Donovan stares at the photo of the innocent young man.
Hoffman strides toward Donovan, who is wrapped in a blank for warmth, and sets down a cup of tea for him and a bott of wine. Michener and Pinker read newspapers in the background.
“Schischkin”? He’s not an embassy secretary. Ivan Schischkin is the KGB’s chief in Western Europe.
Well -- okay. Whatever he is. He’s relaying the proposal to Moscow and they’1l decide -- could I borrow your coat? I lost mine. Hoffman stares at him, thrown by the veer off-course.
How did you lose your coat?
You know. Spy stuff. (CONTINUED)
Hoffman gazes at him, deadpan. Finally:
I’1ll get you another coat.
Good. Good. So -- who is this Vogel?

Him we don’t know. He might be what you said he is, friend of the Attorney General. Just some guy the GDR tapped to handle this. Sounds like the East Germans are fighting for a place at our table. The GDR gets Abel back for the Russians, winning their respect, and captures the headlines for their cause. Which of course puts East Germany on the map. But we don’t care about their map. Stick with the Russians. Stick with the Russians. It’s Powers for Abel.
So, does all this mean it might actually -- happen?

That's what you seem to be telling me. We’ll put Abel on a plane, he’ll be here Friday. So if Schischkin gets the okay, all that’s left is the mechanics of the trade, how we swap our guy for their guy.
Our guys. Two guys. Powers and Pryor.

No! Don’t go bleeding heart on me! Powers is the whole ballgame. Forget this Ivy League boy, who obviously thought it was a good idea to study Soviet economics in Berlin in the middle of the Cold War. Powers is who we need.
You don’t even like Powers. Everybody hates Powers. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)
He didn’t kill himself, he let the commies parade him on television, he’s the most hated man in America. After Rudolf Abel, maybe. And me.
Gary Powers, fitfully sleeping. Two guards reach in to haul him up.
No, no...
Gary Powers being marched down a hall.
Being pushed down onto a seat in a dark interrogation roo He blinks blearily as a bright overhead light ignites.
I need to sleep. I need to sleep.

I told you: you can sleep once we talk. But we need to talk. You must focus on me. Your government does not care about you. You know that. Any of you. You know that twelve U-2 pilots incurred brain damage. They are vegetables. Because of altitude, insufficient oxygen. But they keep you flying, Gary. You and your friends. They gave you this, didn’t they? (holding out the silver dollar) A scratcher, yes, potassium cyanide? (pops open the coin) Does that look like they care about you?

Gary Powers being marched back to his cell.  12.17.14 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 79. GARY POWERS’ CELL Gary Powers is escorted to his bed, where he flops down, instantly closing his eyes. The overhead light goes out. The cell door slams closed. A time jump... Now the overhead light glares on. Gary Powers’ door is fl open. Two men pull him to his feet and drag the still sleeping Powers out into the hallway.
Powers marched down the long hall.
Powers in the chair. His eyes fluttering between wake and sleep. A bucket of cold water poured over his head. Four interrogate him.
What is the construction of the destructor unit? By what means is this unit operated?
With what explosives is the unit charged? And what destruction is it capable of?
I don’t know. The pilots were never shown any of the equipment.
How wide-far can the radar map an area during an overflight?
I don’t know! I don’t know!
Were you making the overflight on April 9th, over the industrial area and the bomber base.
I was not. This was my first overflight. (CONTINUED)

I need to know about engine out-to- glide ratio-- how the plane get so high. We know it reaches altitude of 70,000 feet. Gary, we know this. I need to know where the planes have flown. Where they have flown, Gary. And we must have this talk now. Now. And then, you can sleep a little.
Powers locked back into his cell.
Abel sleeping. A hand enters to shake him awake.
Sir... Abel stirs, looks up. A civilian, not a guard, stands over him. This is Avalon. Two other civilians linger at the door.
Sir, could you come with me please? We need to move, could you come with me? Abel groggily sits up, swings his legs out.
..-What time is it?
It’s late. But we need to talk, and then get on a plane.
Donovan sits before Schischkin.
So, I have received a favorable decision from Moscow on your proposal that we help our friends in the German Democratic Republic, by exchanging Mr. Powers for Mr. Abel. (CONTINUED)
That’s swell!
May I suggest the Glienicke Bridge as a place for the swap.
Why not Checkpoint Charlie?
Well, we are not looking for publicity! Glienicke Bridge is very quiet. Especially early morning.
Glienicke Bridge, I‘1l run that by our side. We can have Abel here on Friday, so -- Saturday morning?
Always impatient, yes?
Yeah, I’ve gotta get back home and get into bed. So, Saturday morning?
All right. We’re done here. This is a number (writing)...in case anything should come up...Someone will answer, at any hour.
(taking the paper) All right. I don’t expect to use it. Shall we toast the arrangement?
Why not. Schischkin heads for a sideboard, holds up a bottle.
Armenian brandy. Good bracer for your cold. (CONTINUED)
Thank you. Would you mind -- it’s not part of our business but I’d like to ask a couple of questions? You do not have to answer.
I shall answer what I know. Schischkin returns with the drinks.
I like this guy. Your guy. What happens to your guy...when he gets home?
Well. We have to make a determination whether our guy is now...your guy.
As I said to you before, he’s acted very honorably. He’s still your guy, believe me.
Of course: you would say this if it were true, and if it were not true.
Yeah. I guess it has come down to that... Forgive me for pushing, but...is he in any danger? If the determination is made...
Well, goodness. As things are now, everyone is in danger. Cheers. He raises his glass. Donovan toasts him in Russian. The toast is interrupted by a knock. A secretary puts his head in.
A message for Mister Donovan... VOGEL’S OFFICE The familiar squalid counterpoint to Schischkin’s Louis X swank. (CONTINUED)

Dapper Vogel in a new change, as incongruously fine in th office as was his last one. But his manner is different, at all the happy fixer of yesterday. His tone is cold as Donovan, dabbing at his nose, is shown in.
There will be no exchange on Glienicke Bridge. Vogel rises and reaches for some files he puts into his briefcase.
Excuse me, sir.
There will be no exchange. Not for Frederic Pryor.
Mr. Vogel. I thought yesterday -- we agreed --

We agreed on an exchange: Abel for Pryor. Now I learn you are a rug merchant selling the same rug to two customers. Abel for Pryor, you sell to us. Abel for Powers, you sell to the Soviets. Vogel's secretary helps him on with his overcoat and scar
.-.I’m not sure I understand the problem. If the arrangement satisfies two parties, or three, or four, what difference --
The arrangement does not satisfy this party. He exits into the corridor and Donovan follows.
Now Mr. Vogel, please --
Obviously you do not know who you are dealing with. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

Here is the interest of the German Democratic Republic: to deal with, and to be seen to be dealing with, another sovereign power, the United States. An equal power. Instead you treat us as stooges for the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.
Can we just call them “the Russians” -- it’ll save time.
I have an appointment sir. I think it is you who are wasting time. He heads down the stairs; Donovan follows.

Tell me if I’m describing this wrong. You have a kid, a university student, somebody you know is not a spy, and no threat to you. In exchange for this person, worthless to you, you play an equal part in an exchange with two other powers, the Americans and the Russians.
The two men emerge from the building.

It’s one transaction, between us and the two of you. We’re not trying to do two different things here. It’s one thing. One one one. And it’s hard for me to see how the Republic of East German Democrats is being slighted.
You arranged with the Soviets without consulting me. Is this a negotiation -- or a conspiracy?

For it to be a conspiracy, there would have to be some harm to you, sir. There’s just benefits here. We have agreeing interests -- 84. Vogel is climbing into a fancy sports car parked at the c (CONTINUED)
No. You decide they agree.
Where’s is your appointment, sir?
In the West.
Good. Donovan opens the passenger door and climbs inside.

text: Look around you. 85. The car is racing through a desolate cityscape. Donovan d look around; takes it in.

How does the Eastern sector compare to the West? (no answer) Our Russian friends have decided that we should not rebuild our capital city. We live in this ruin. Made by our Russian friends. Go ahead, make your deal with these Russians, but we won't be part of it.
There is no deal without Pryor. We’re not leaving him here. The car rounds a corner at speed.
Is that your position, or your government's?
I'm here. I’m talking to you.
But you’re not a representative of the government. You don’t know who you are. Neither do we. You should be careful. This is not Brooklyn, Mr. Donovan. (CONTINUED)
The speedometer, the needle at 120kph
Sir: you must know that in the respect that matters, I represent my government. You know who I am.
Do I?

Uh-oh. Donovan looks behind. A police detail comes up on their tail. Vogel downshifts, lifting his foot off the gas. Vogel pulls over. Donovan is suddenly nervous as they ski to a stop. The police sedan pulls up behind them.

Do you have the proper papers? Oh, no of course you don’t. It doesn’t matter. An expensive American lawyer like you can talk your way out of anything. Can’t you. Vogel gets out of the car. He speaks to the cops in Germa Nods toward Donovan, saying he’s an American. The cops tr Vogel deferentially -- but not Donovan.
(sharpy, in German, to Donovan as he opens the passenger door.) You, get out now. Donovan climbs out of the car, hands over his passport.
(in German) Passport. Donovan hesitates, he looks at Vogel. The checkpoint guard checks Donovan’s passport, shouts something in German to another guard, and then to Donovan English. (CONTINUED)
Go with him.
Why?
Passport. Problem.
What? What’s wrong with it? What problem? The other guard has stepped in, hand on his gun.
Go with him. As Vogel is led away:
And remember. We control the fate of Frederic Pryor.
Pryor is awake. Pacing. His light is off as he can see an armed guard positioned on the grate above. Pryor is utter terrified.
Powers, eyes open, alone in his cell and staring at the p and pencils on the table in front of him.
Avalon leads Abel to a seat. Abel is holding a cardboard tube.
A holding room door is opened. Donovan rises from the uncomfortable bench he’s been on.
Donovan asleep in a train seat. He opens his eyes. His co is worse. (CONTINUED)

The train chugs along. A bleary look to his window. Point-of-view: lit by the beginnings of day, the Wall is coming at us, foreshortening, opposite-ways from when we it on Donovan's first trip in. As it sweeps by there is movement and a shout goes up. Donovan stands, gazes out the window in horror. Four figures at the wall. They are riddled with gunfire, dangling and dropping to the eastern side, the other two dropping dead to the western side. Inside the train the passengers react in horror and Donov collapses back into his seat, devastated.
Donovan, haggard, in the restaurant, looking at a menu. A waitress approaches.
I'll start with some coffee, please. And then I’1l have the Hilton Combo, and the American Breakfast. And coffee.
Both breakfasts?
(handing menu back) Yeah. Yeah.
One first, or...
Both first. Both, whenever they’re ready. And coffee. The waitress moves off. Hoffman approaches, sits.
You shouldn’t be here.
Well sometimes in Germany you just want a big American breakfast. Michener and Pinker cross and takes seats at a nearby tab (CONTINUED)
What happened? Where were you last night?
Mr. Vogel arranged for me to spend some time in the East.
Jesus.

Not much worse than what you got for me here in the west. So the Russians are fine with the exchange, but Vogel now says the East Germans won't do it. We’re not gonna get Pryor. Hoffman stares at him.
Great. Good. So the Soviets are set. We get Powers. We get Powers. Well done. He gives a thumbs up to Michener and Pinker, sitting at a table nearby.
No, the East Germans won't do it. We won’t get Pryor. And look, that kid matters, every person matters.
Sure, that’s why we tried. Abel’s on his way, so we're all set for tomorrow morning.
Wait a minute --
Makes things simple.
But we’re not getting the kid.
Yeah, I understand. We’re set. We can ignore the message we got this morning. (CONTINUED)
He leaves. 12.17.14 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 90. (2)
What message?
From from the East Germans. They called the number I gave you, said they wanted to speak to you today.
Vogel called?
No. Office of Harald Ott. East German attorney general.
Wanting what -- what does he want?
To talk to you, but -- it’s okay, I can’t ask you to go back there. Listen, you seem to be persona non grata to some elements. We won’t push our luck.
So he wants to see me. What time?
No no no, now listen, you don’t need to go -- in fact, you shouldn't go. In fact you can’t go. We’re set with the Soviets, we don’t want to screw it up.
(rising) I’m not going to screw it up.
You're not going, don’t be a pain in the ass.
Oh, I ordered. Enjoy your big American breakfast. Several waitresses deposit mountains of food before an abashed Hoffman.  12.17.14 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT gl.

Architecturally grand in a beaux-art manner but cracked a peeling. Furnishings sparse and poor. A heavy middle-aged man shakes Donovan's hand. A male secretary to one side sits taking notes as the Ott and Donovan take their seats at Ott’s desk.. ort I thought it should be negotiated at the highest level. As a courtesy to you.
Well I thank you sir. ort I don’t know how things became so confused.

Well... I guess sometimes they just do. Female servers clear a large conference table of dishes. ort For sake of clarity, I say we are fully prepared to exchange the so- called student Pryor for Rudolf Abel. I understand from Mr. Vogel that Pryor is very important to you.
Yes sir. But -- ort We will do a memorandum to that effect.
A memorandum. ort (generous) Certainly. We commit to a bilateral exchange --
Yes, sure, I’m not sure what you mean, but -- my country also insists on Francis Gary Powers. (CONTINUED)
ort (rising and pounding on the table) No!! One of the women drops her dishware, apologizes.

-- this is how things became confused. Powers -- what use is he, sir? You want him back for punitive reasons? What’s done is done, he has divulged what he will divulge, as no doubt Abel has also. We are offering instead someone who you insist is innocent. And this is right. This is who you should retrieve. The future! Look to the future. A phone among a bank of phones rings. Ott picks up a receiver.
ott! Oops, wrong phone. He picks up another.
ott. He speaks in German for a while, then, to Donovan:
I’m sorry. If you could give me a moment, sir.
Big echoing public space. Donovan is seated on a hard ben Bicycle messengers whiz by in both directions. The secretary’s footsteps echo as he crosses to Donovan.
I am very sorry sir. The Attorney General regrets that he had to leave on urgent business.
..-He -- left? (CONTINUED)
Yes, many apologies.
I've been waiting for over an hour to --
Very sorry, sir. He turns and walks away, echoing footsteps, Donovan stari Suddenly Donovan projects:
Young man! The young man stops, looks back.
..-C’mere! Hesitation.
-It’s all right, c’mere. The secretary crosses back.
Take a seat. He taps the bench next to himself.
Oh c’mon, c’mon, sit down. Somewhat bewildered, the young man complies. Donovan is friendly:
-You like your job here?
(genuine) It’s a very good job, sir.
Must be. Must be interesting.
Yes sir. (CONTINUED)
